title: Designer Profile: Rachel Greig
content:
Rarely is a Spring/Summer collection able to combine foil fringing, medieval nun’s headgear and crumpled morning-after the night-before bedsheets, and succeed in maintaining any kind of worthy message.

London College of Fashion graduate Rachel Greig borrows silhouette and fabric inspiration from classical 15th century paintings – take the pleated ‘wimple’, a headdress traditionally worn by medieval women – and injects them with comical references to the modern drink and drug culture typically exemplified by young Brits abroad.

Throughout this collection the concept of the pilgrimage is approached both as a metaphorical and a physical journey, concluding in a gloriously eccentric metafictional account of the two. Not only are we led to consider the static state of ridiculousness in a contrast of religious pilgrimage versus ‘lads’ hol’; there is also a process of personal development underway within the collection itself, for which the rite of passage journey – in whatever form it may take – is deemed a fast-working catalyst.

Gold and silver fringing and jersey numbers splattered across the backs of garments give the looks a sport-luxe feel, and allude to the pack mentality and uniform in groups of bronzed post-teen ASBO’s on a ten day bender in Magaluf. The garments move and shimmer down the catwalk with buoyant energy: in particular the gold fringed coat, which stands tall, proud, and inappropriate, like an over-enthusiastically decorated Christmas tree. In August.

It seems the designer’s experience interning at Giles Deacon last year earned her a dose of Deacon’s infamous sense of artistic humour. And she wears it well.
